subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Improved protocol
author: SnowfireL@aol.com
full_text:
--part1_80e7e.195927ec.396b4e13_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="UTF-8"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Language: en

I am sorry now that I got involved in this testing, this is not a science  =

class, and I am sorry list members, I was unaware of what they were up to.=
 
no  wonder David (the tech) did not want to get involved.  We don't know =
 who 
people are on these lists to begin with, and I should have been  more=
 
careful, getting old.  sf
 
 
In a message dated 7/11/2010 11:37:38 A.M. =
Eastern Daylight Time,  
rasterer@... writes:

 
 
 
Your points are =
well taken John.  And I agree it is  a first attempt and 
certainly can be =
improved on successive trials, and  cannot determine the 
origin of the mes=
sages.

For this first  experiment/protocolFor this first  
experiment/prot=
ocol<WBR>, I thought we would go as generic as possible:  it doesn't matter=
 really 
here where the information comes from, or how  different people in=
terpret it: 
just determin  We'll start with data on how accurate the parti=
cipants  can 
get, however they do it.

As to your comment on the audio  fi=
les:  originally I considered requiring 
as part of the protocol  to includ=
e the audio.  Maybe that is still a good 
idea.  The  reason I didn't, is b=
ecause people often claim to hear different 
things  each time they listen =
to a file.  Posting a file with an incorrect  
answer, for example, the per=
son may later claim (after the experiment)  to 
NOW hear the right answer. =
 And others may confirm  it.

This seemed liked a rabbit hole, and I'm not =
sure how to  handle it. So for 
this trial, I figured we'd just not go ther=
e, and  require replies only be 
valid if they are given during the experim=
ents  specified time frame. Once 
the actual object is know, it seems too e=
asy  for a person to come up with 
the answer.

But yeah, we need to see  h=
ow this goes, fix the problems, and come up with 
more of  them!

--- On Su=
n, 7/11/10, John S  <phenom_investigatorphenom_inv> wrote:


From:  John S =
<phenom_investigatorphenom_inv>
Subject:  [EVP-ITC] Improved protocol
To:  =
EVP-ITC@yahoogroupsTo: 
Date: Sunday, July 11, 2010, 8:08  AM


 
 
 
Since=
 we're talking about experiments and protocols here are some  ideas to 
imp=
rove
the protocol RJ suggested initially. Using a test target is one  way o=
f 
establishing a 
truth in time, which is the basis of this experiment. Bu=
t there  are a 
couple of issues.
 
It is quite possible that someone could=
 discern the target  through remote 
viewing alone.
This would negate the n=
eed for involvement of a spirit  communicator or 
discarnate entity.
Outcom=
es depend on the word of those reporting. The true  skeptic (not 
cynic) wo=
uld 
therefore say that this experiment contains a basic flaw in that  it d=
oes 
not uniquely 
indicate that the information was obtained in the prescr=
ibed  manner. 
Providing access
to the raw audio file would not necessarily=
 constitute proof  either, since 
many of these 
communications can only be=
 heard by certain people, 
 
If the audio file were quite clear, timing  be=
comes an  issue. In other 
words, when was 
the audio actually recorded?  T=
his issue can be mitigated  simply by 
requiring any
claimant to email the =
audio file to a trusted party before the  test ends. 
It would be best 
if =
the trusted party were not otherwise involved in the  experiment and it 
wa=
s  their duty 
simply to collect the claims. Once all claims had been  coll=
ected they 
could be posted 
publicly for review by the community in genera=
l.  The  experimenter could 
decide if any 
of the claims seemed to have hi=
t, and this decision could be  reviewed by 
anyone if desired. 
 
The impor=
tant detail however is that this experiment does not  completely 
answer th=
e 
question. It is a first attempt and certainly can be improved on  
succe=
ssive trials.
 
Successive trials are always a good idea, since it provides=
  replication. 
And it would be
best if others replicated the experiment us=
ing a very similar  protocol. If 
these were to
succeed, the community coul=
d then state that out of X trials Y  had 
succeeded (by 
some definition of=
 success) potentially giving a success  rate above that 
expected 
by rando=
m chance. This would make the outcome quantifiable and  measureable 
and th=
us meaningful.
 
But also important to note, this would only prove the pote=
ntial  veracity 
of the messages.
It would not (and cannot as far as I can =
tell) prove the origin  of the 
messages. This detail
will, I fear, remain =
a matter for belief and speculation for  quite some 
time to come.
 
 
 


=








--part1_80e7e.195927ec.396b4e13_boundary
